quote: Nah. We're due uptown in fifteen minutes.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Take your picture and get out of here.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: This time, you're getting off with a warning. Next time, you won't be so lucky.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: You heard him, move it.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: I tell you, Kevin. This city's going to hell in a handbasket.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Damn shame.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: "And he said to me, 'These words are trustworthy and true.' And the Lord, the God of the spirits of the prophets, has sent his angel to show his servants what must soon take place."
"Then the eyes of the blind shall be opened, and the ears of the deaf shall be unstopped." Praise the Lord, open their eyes. Help them to see.
Are you talking to me?
"Oh, that my words were now written! Oh, that they were printed in a book!" Write those words, Brother Benny. Let them see the glory of what lies ahead.
How do you know my name?
Go now and write the truth that's in your heart. The truth "that shall set them free!"
Praise be the word of the Lord... Praise to the word of the prophets. Hallelujah, brothers and sisters.
Hey, baby. Have a seat. The usual?
How 'bout scrambling the eggs today?
My aren't we feeling adventurous.
I just finished the best story I've ever written.
That's great, baby. I got some good news, too.
I talked to Mrs. Jackson last night. She's serious about retiring in the next couple of ears. I asked her about selling this place to us and she said she'd be willing.
Cassie, we've been over this. I have a job. I'm a writer.
And how much money have you earned doing that?
I've only been working at it for a few years.
A few years? More like fifteen -- if you count all those stories you wrote in the Navy.
That was amateur stuff.

Baby, neither one of us is getting any younger. Don't you see? This is our chance. we can make some money. Get married. You're always writing about the future -- well, look around - this is our future.
Hey there, Cassie. Hear the game last night? I went two for four and robbed Snider of a tater. You shoulda heard the crowd -- the way they were yelling and carrying on...
Sure they were yelling. They want to know why the Giants are in fifth place.
Why don't you tell this fool to take his business someplace else.
I've thought about it. Trouble is, if he did leave, he'd take my heart with him.
Suit yourself. But if you ask me, you're wasting an awfully pretty heart.
I don't think so.
Strike three. You're out.
That's all right, I'll get another turn at bat. Now how about frying me up some steak and eggs?
Coming right up. But first, tell me something -- how come you're still living uptown? A famous ballplayer like you can live anywhere he wants.
The hell I can. They can hardly get used to me playing alongside them on the ballfield... living next to 'em -- that's a whole other story.
Besides, around here, when people look at me, it's 'cause they admire me. There, I'm just a colored boy who can hit a curve ball.
Now, if you'll excuse me, my public awaits.
I'll see to those eggs.
Hey, Benny -- wanna buy a watch?
Where'd you get that?
I found it. Nice, huh?
One of these days, Jimmy, you're going to find yourself in serious trouble.
Anything I can get into, I can get out of.
You keep thinking that -- see what happens.
Man, how come you're always lecturing me?
I'm not lecturing you -- I'm trying to help you.
You want to help me, buy this watch. I could use the cash.
Why not get a job?
As what -- a delivery boy or a dishwasher? No, thanks. I like being my own boss. Setting my own hours.
Sounds like a great life.
Yours ain't no better. Writing stories about a bunch of white people living on the moon. Who cares about that?
I'm not doing that anymore. I'm writing about us.
What -- colored people on the moon?
Check out next month's issue.
Colored people on the moon... I just might do that.
But first, I'm gonna need to raise me some cash.
She has a worm in her belly? That's disgusting. Interesting, but disgusting.
Who... that is, if you don't mind me asking... are, uh...
I'm Mister Pabst's new secretary. Darlene Kursky. Which one of you wrote this?
I did.
You?
Surprise.
It's the best thing I've read since "The Puppet Masters." (a beat, almost apologetic) I read a lot of science fiction.
Bless you, my child.
The world needs more people like you.
The story really... I mean to say... it's quite...
... impressive?
It's a damn fine piece of writing is what it is. And "Deep Space Nine" is a very intriguing title.
Very admirable.
The master of understatement. What he really means is that he wishes he had half your talent.
I really like this major of yours... she's a tough cookie.
Science fiction needs more strong women characters. I'm always saying that, aren't I, Jules?
Ad nauseam, my dear.
These Cardassians... I like how you've described them. Their neck ridges especially. I'll come up with some sketches to show you. It could make a nice cover.
Don't waste your time.
You, back to work.
Right away, Mister Pabst.
You too, Roy.
Douglas -- you're not going to stand there and tell us you don't like this story.
Oh, I like it all right. It's good. Very good.
But you know I can't print it.
Why not?
Come on, Benny -- your hero's a Negro captain. The head of a space station, for Christ's sake.
What's wrong with that?
People won't accept it. It's not believable.
And men from Mars are?

Stay out of this, Herb. Look, Benny, I'm a magazine editor -- not a crusader. I'm not here to change the world. I'm here to put out a magazine. That's my job. And that means I've got to answer to Mister Stone, the national distributors, the wholesalers -- -- and none of them are going to want to put this on the newsstand. For all we know, it could cause a race riot.
Congratulations, Douglas. That's the most imbecilic attempt to rationalize personal cowardice I've ever heard.
Uh-oh, he's angry now.
Herb's been angry ever since Joseph Stalin died.
What's that supposed to mean?
You know exactly what it means.
You calling me a red?
Easy.
Calm down, dear boy. We're writers, not vikings.
I'm not going to let some craven fascist call me a pinko and get away with it.
Douglas, what'd you... uh, think of my story?
I loved it. You see, Albert's got the right idea. He's not interested in Negroes or whites -- he writes about robots.
That's because he is a robot. No offense, Albert.
I... uh, like robots. They're very... efficient.
Here, write me a novella based on this drawing and I'll print it in next month's issue. Do a good job and you might even get the cover.
(holding up his manuscript) What about my story?
The way I see it, you can either burn it or you can put it in a drawer for fifty years or however long it takes the human race to become colorblind.
But I want people to read it now.
Fine. You want me to publish it? Then make the captain white.
But that's not what I wrote.
It's your call..
I'm sorry they didn't buy your story, baby. Really I am.
I told you you were wasting your time. A colored captain... the only reason they'll ever let us space is if they need someone to shine their shoes. Ain't that right, Cassie?
I don't know and to be honest, I don't much care what happens a hundred years from now. It's today that matters.
Well I got news for you... today or a hundred years from now don't make a bit of difference -- as far as they're concerned, we'll always be niggers.
Things are going to change. They have to.
(not buying it for a second) You keep telling yourself that.
Maybe all this is happening for a reason.
You mean maybe this is God's way of telling me to quit writing and go into the restaurant business?

Hey, it's possible. Baby, I know we could make this work for us. We could be happy here. Besides, you don't have to give up writing altogether... maybe you could write something for the Amsterdam News or one of the other Negro newspapers.
I'm not a reporter. I write fiction -- and the Amsterdam News isn't going to publish stories about a space station four hundred years in the future.
Hear the game last night?
Hey, I'm sorry -- I didn't mean to frighten you.
You don't look so good. You sick or something?
I'm fine.
Want to lie down in the back?
I just need some air.
We still on for tonight?
I'll pick you up around ten.
So what're you doing 'til ten?
Whatever it is, I'm not doing it with you.
Hello, Brother Benny.
You again? I don't understand... what do you want from me?
To follow the path of the Prophets. Walk with the Prophets, Brother Benny. Show us the way.
What way? I don't know what you're talking about.
Write the words, Brother Benny. The words that will lead us out of the darkness and onto the path of righteousness.
Write the words, Brother Benny. Write the words.
Hey, baby. You forgot all about our date.
Date? Oh, yeah -- that's right. I'm sorry. I was working...
Ben Sisko? Isn't that your colored captain? Why are you writing another one of those stories? You couldn't sell the last one. What makes you think this one will be any different?
It probably won't be. Doesn't matter. It's what I've got to do.
Right now, what you've got to do is eat.
I'm not hungry.
What time is it anyway?
A little after midnight. I should be getting home to bed. But before I go --
-- what do you say we take one spin around the dance floor.
Feels good, doesn't it?
I could stay like this forever.
Me, too. It's times like these that I wish we'd never heard of the Dominion.
scene: 48   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: The Dominion?
scene: 48   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: What do you mean? You said something about the Dominion...
What is it, Ben? What's wrong?
scene: 50   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: I don't know -- I think I'm losing my mind...
scene: 50   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: Why? Tell me -- what's wrong?
(knows how odd this sounds) I'm starting to see things... things from my story... it's as if I'm becoming Captain Sisko.
Baby, you need to get some rest.
It's all right, baby. I'm here. Just take it easy... I'm with you.
Have you lost your mind?
Lately, I've been asking myself the same question.

I give you a novella to write - even offered you a shot at the cover -- and three weeks later, instead of a novella, you come back with six stories -- six sequels to a story I refused to publish in the first place. So I guess the answer to the question we've both been asking is yes - you're certifiable!
You might consider printing those stories yourself -- you know, through a private publishing house. A nice, elegant, little volume. Fifty to a hundred copies.
That's a great idea.
He may as well write them in chalk on the sidewalk. More people would read them that way.
You tell him, Kay. I know a good divorce lawyer if you need one.
I've got an idea. Why not make it... you know, a dream?
What's that?
Uh... you know, make the ending... of your first story -- "Deep Space Nine" -- a dream.
Will that make a difference?
That depends...
On what?
On who's doing the dreaming.
Obviously, someone without much hope. A shoeshine boy or a convict -- dreaming of a better future.
A Negro?
I suppose he'd have to be... if he's dreaming about a Negro captain.
Hold on -- making it a dream guts the whole story.
Shaddup, Herbert.
(disagreeing with Herbert) I think it makes it more poignant.
But what about your other Sisko stories? You can't make them all dreams.
Let him get the first one published. He can worry about the others later.
What do you think, Benny?
I think it's better than chalk on the sidewalk...
-- bottom of seventh I come up again. And on an oh-two fastball -- BAM. Into the centerfield bleachers. Had to be at least four hundred feet.
I know all about it, Willie. I read the newspaper.
Yeah, but you gotta admit -- they don't tell it as well as I do.
Cassie.
Hey, man. Hear the game last night? I went two for four.
That's great, Willie. But I just hit a grand slam.
They're publishing one of my Sisko stories. And at three cents a word.
Good for you, baby.
Tonight, we're celebrating. Dinner, dancing -- the works.
I'll wear my red dress.
You're damn right you will.
My poor feet... baby, you better marry me soon. I'm not getting any younger.
But you are getting more and more beautiful.
Brother Benny.
I was hoping I'd see you again. I did it. My story's going to be published.
"The light of the Lord is in his path." But, this is only the beginning of your journey -- not the ending. And the path of the Prophets sometimes leads into darkness and pain.
Benny, what's he talking about? Who are you?
I speak with the voice of the Prophets.
And in their words, hope and despair walk arm in arm.
Did you understand any of that?
Is that gunfire?
The time has come, Brother Benny. Go and "be of good courage."
Jimmy!
Get back.
What happened?
What's it to you?
I know him --
Yeah? Then maybe you can explain what he was doing trying to break into that car.
Is that why you shot him? For breaking into a car?
He had a weapon.
A crowbar?
I said -- stay back!
Stop it! Please!
Don't! You're killing him!
I'm telling you, baby -- you've been cooped up in this apartment too long. Going down to the office will do you good.
I suppose I should be there when the first copies of this month's issue are delivered.
Absolutely. After all that work you did -- you deserve to see your story in print. Just no jumping up and down with excitement -- I wouldn't want you to hurt yourself.
I'll restrict myself to a proud grin.
You're not having any more of those... hallucinations, are you?
I'm fine.
Hey, Benny -- long time no see.
Is it here?
Not yet. Pabst is still at the printers.
But we're all waiting for his return with baited breath.
We heard... you know, that you were... ah...
We heard they beat the hell out of you.
I'm okay.
Glad to see that you're... ah... you know, up... and about.
Tell him the good news, Albert.
It's... nothing really.
Nothing? He sold a novel to Gnome Press and he calls it nothing.
A novel -- congratulations! Robots?
What else?
It's about time.
Hey, Douglas -- where's the magazine?
There is no magazine. Not this month anyway. Mister Stone had the entire run pulped.
He can't do that!
He can and he did. He believes that this issue quote -- did not meet our usual high standards -- unquote.
And what's that supposed to mean?
It means he didn't like it.
Which means the public's simply going to have to get along without any Incredible Tales this month.
You still haven't said what he didn't like. The artwork? The layout? Exactly what "high standards" is he talking about?
Take it easy, Benny.
It's about my story, isn't it? That's what this is all about. He didn't want to publish my story -- and we all know why. Because my hero is a colored man.
Hey -- Mister Stone owns this magazine. If he doesn't want to publish this month -- we don't publish this month. End of story.
That doesn't make it right and you know it.
Don't tell me what I know. Besides, it's not about what's right -- it's about what is.
I'm afraid I have some more bad news, Benny. Mister Stone has decided your services are no longer required here.
You're firing me?
I have no choice, Benny. It's his decision.
Well you can't fire me -- I quit. To hell with Stone and to hell with you.
Try to stay calm.
I'm tired of being calm. Calm's never gotten me a damn thing.
I'm warning you, Benny -- if you don't stop shouting, I'm calling the cops.
Call them! Go ahead! They can't do anything to me. Not anymore. None of you can.

I'm a human being, dammit! You can deny me all you want but you can't deny Ben Sisko. He exists! That space station -- those people -- that future -- they exist! In here. And in the minds of everyone of you who read it.
You hear what I'm telling you? You can pulp the story but you can't destroy the idea. That future is real -- I made it real! You hear me -- it's real! It's real! It's real!
Rest easy, Brother Benny.
You've walked in the path of the Prophets. There is no greater glory.
Tell me, please. Who am I?
Don't you know?
Tell me!
You're the dreamer. And the dream.
Ben!
How long was I out?
Only a few minutes.
Seemed like forever to me.
That's odd. Somehow, your neural patterns have returned to normal.
That's good, isn't it?
It's very good. I just don't understand why it happened.
Come in.
How're you feeling, son?
Okay.
I'm done packing. Transport leaves at eight in the morning.
I wish you could stay longer.
I've got to get back to the restaurant. My customers have never gone this long without me. The question is -- what are you going to do?
The only thing I can do. Stay here and finish the job I started. And if I fail...
"I have fought the good fight. I have finished the course. I have kept the faith."
I've never known you to quote the Bible.
I'm full of surprises, aren't I? And so are you... sounds like this dream you had helped you sort things out.
I suppose it did. But I've been wondering... what if it wasn't a dream? What if this life we're leading... all of this... you and me -- everything... what if all this is the illusion?
That's a scary thought.
I know... but maybe, just maybe, Benny isn't the dream -- we are. Maybe we're nothing more than figments of his imagination.
For all we know, at this very moment, somewhere, far beyond all those stars... Benny Russell is dreaming of us.
Got you this time, Chief.
Sorry, Commander.
Don't apologize, that just makes it worse.
I guess I'm in the zone today.
The zone?
That feeling that I can't lose... that I can put the dart exactly where I want it. You know the feeling.
Not today.
Dax to Sisko.
Go ahead.
Benjamin, there's a priority message for you from the Bajoran Provisional Government.
On my way. Fortunately, duty calls. You'll have to find another victim.
Doctor.
Commander. Is the chief here?
He's back there... in the zone.
... raka-ja ut shala morala... ema bo roo kana... uranak...
... ralanon Bareil... propeh va nara ehsuk shala-kan vunek ... (do not let him walk alone... guide him on his journey... protect... the one named Bareil... take him into the gates of heaven... )
Enter.
I'm sorry. I didn't mean to interrupt.
It's all right.
It's called a duranja -- a lamp for the dead. I've been... praying for Bareil.
What can I do for you?
This may come as something of a shock and I wanted you to hear it from me. The First Minister of the Provisional Government has died.
Kalem Apren? How?
Heart failure... he died in his sleep.
I only met him once, but he seemed like a good man. How soon will they appoint someone to replace him?
They've already appointed someone. The new head of the Provisional Government... is Kai Winn.
... so as a result, I've transferred Ensign Palmers back to the night watch and reassigned Crewman Donark to the Defiant as a member of the security detachment.
Starfleet is sending a series of upgrades for our tactical computer modules next week. I've drawn up a plan to phase in the upgrades over the course of three days.
Major. Is something wrong?
No. Yes.
It's this... whole thing with Kai Winn.
I was just getting used to thinking of her as the spiritual leader of Bajor. But now she's running the entire government, Odo.
Not an ideal situation.

I'm beginning to think that you and I are the only ones who feel that way. No one's even going to oppose her in next month's elections. She's going to be elected First Minister for the next six years and no one seems to care.
You and I have a different perspective than most Bajorans, Major. There's a... personal element to our feelings about her. I know you still blame Winn for Bareil's death.
That's part of it. But this is about the future of Bajor. I can't shake the feeling that giving Winn control of the government is a mistake... She has to be stopped...
Stopped from doing what?
I don't know. Maybe I'm afraid that once she's in power... she's never going to let go.
Unfortunately, that suspicion is not shared by the people of Bajor.
They still admire her as... the woman who made peace with Cardassia.
Bareil made peace with Cardassia.

I know that, Major. But to the rest of Bajor, Winn is the real hero... in their eyes, it took courage for her to conclude a treaty with a race that she herself had so bitterly condemned and fought against.
I don't care about her... popular image, she's no hero. She only cares about one thing... her own power. Why can't people see that?

We spent all those years fighting against the Cardassians... all that time spent hoping and praying for a Bajor that was free... now, after we've won, how can people hand their freedom over to someone like Winn?
It has been my observation that one of the prices of giving people freedom of choice... is that sometimes they make the wrong choice.
I think I'll stick to Tongo from now on.
Sorry, Lieutenant.
Thank you, thank you all for your gaming business. The House will start taking bets on the next challenger at ten to one. That's ten to one, without even knowing who the next challenger will be.
Quark, I have to go.
No problem. Ladies and gentlemen, Chief of Operations Miles Edward O'Brien now has to leave to resume his duties aboard the station.
Now, everyone, give him room... make way, make way...
I trust that we'll be seeing you again tomorrow, for your... forty- seventh straight victory, Chief?
I don't know... I was actually thinking about getting some time in the holosuites tomorrow.
The holosuites? You weren't thinking of... going kayaking by any chance?
As a matter of fact...
Oh... didn't I tell you? I misplaced the kayaking program -- haven't seen it in days.

All right, look -- you're on a streak -- an epic streak. If you go kayaking tomorrow... and something happens... and you damage that... golden shoulder... this streak will be over. And you'll never know just how far it might have taken you. Could you really live with that?
You're offering ten to one tomorrow to anyone betting against me?
That's right.
I'd make it fifteen.
... bo roo kana... uranak... ralanon Bareil... propeh va nara ehsuk shala- kan ...
Yes?
Hello, child.
Eminence...
May I come in?
Of course.
I hope you'll forgive the intrusion child, I know the hour is late...
Does Commander Sisko know that you're aboard the station?
I'm not here to see the Emissary. I'm here to see you.
Me?
Yes, Child.
Have you suffered a recent loss? Or are you still mourning the death of Minister Kalem?
It's for Vedek Bareil, actually.
It's been three months since Bareil left us to walk with the Prophets... you must have cared for him deeply.
I... loved him.
As did I.
Is that why you never mention Bareil's name when you talk about your peace treaty with Cardassia? As I recall, he was the one who negotiated it.

Bareil saw himself as simply carrying out the will of the Prophets. To him, achieving peace with Cardassia was its own reward. He never wanted fame or glory for what he did. As someone who loved him, I'm surprised you didn't know that.
What is it you want, Eminence?
Are you familiar with Rakantha Province?
It's... a farming community.

And it used to be one of the most productive agricultural regions on Bajor. But as you know, the Cardassians poisoned much of our farmlands before they left, and Rakantha has been mostly barren wasteland ever since. After years of research, the agricultural ministry has finally developed reclamators which can detoxify the soil and make it fertile again.
This is all very interesting, but what does this have to do with me?

Patience, Child. In six months, it will be the planting season in Rakantha. By this time next year, we can be producing boton, moreka, salam grass -- all of them valuable commodities for export. If we can attract interstellar commerce to Bajor, it will only enhance our application for membership in the Federation.
I understand...

Unfortunately, a group of farmers who were allowed to use the reclamators in another province are now refusing to return them. That's why I've come to you, Kira. You see, the farmers who've seized the equipment are in Dahkur Province -- your home. And they're led by a man you're acquainted with... his name is Shakaar.
Shakaar?
If I'm not mistaken, he was the leader of your resistance cell during the occupation.
That's right.
I want you to convince him to return the equipment he's stolen.
You're asking me to go against a man who saved my life on about a hundred occasions... for you?
Not for me, child. For Bajor. I know that we've had our differences in the past... but I'm asking you to put those feelings aside and think about what is best for our people.

We are on the verge of a new era... the Occupation is over, we've achieved peace with Cardassia, Federation membership is only a few years away... this is an exciting time to be a Bajoran. But our future depends on each of us acting for the common good of all Bajor. Shakaar has lost sight of that. By stealing the reclamators, he's acting in his own self-interest at the expense of the rest of our people.
I know Shakaar... and he's one of the most... selfless people I ever met. He must have a good reason for what he's done.

Perhaps. Perhaps he is only... misguided. That's why I've come to you, Kira. You know him... you can talk to him. I don't want this to become a... scandal. I want this to be settled quietly, peacefully. Surely we can both agree that that's a worthy goal...
I can... talk to him. But I can't guarantee he'll listen to me.
Vedek Bareil used to tell me that you can be quite persuasive when you put your mind to it, child. I hope that he wasn't mistaken. Walk with the Prophets.
Shakaar.
You cut your hair.
You let yours grow.
I liked you better the old way.
I was just thinking the same thing... about you.
It's good to see you, Nerys.
It's good to see you too.
Come in, come in...
So. Major Kira Nerys. Deep Space Nine's first officer. You've made quite a name for yourself.
Not really.
You've accomplished a great deal. You should be proud.
Furel and Lupaza are so proud of you they actually stand a little taller when your name comes up.
Furel and Lupaza? You still see them?
Of course. They both have farms less than ten kilometers from here.
Those two are farmers? You, yes -- it was all you talked about -- but Lupaza? How'd that happen?
You can ask her yourself. They'll be here in a couple of hours.
I can't wait to see their faces when they come through that door and find you standing here.
Shakaar... before they get here, we should talk. I'm... here on business.
Nerys... I know why you're here. And I need time to think about it. All right?
All right.
You never would've found your way out of there if I hadn't left that marker on the rock.
I have a fine sense of direction. I knew exactly where I was the whole night.
I found your tracks the next day. You were walking in circles.
I was throwing the Cardassians off my trail.
Nerys? Guess who I saw last week? Mobara.
Really?
He's in school now... studying engineering.
That's perfect. Now he can build bridges and then blow them up.
Again, please.
Furel... if you don't mind my asking... why haven't you--

Why haven't I had my arm replaced? Well... I thought about it. Even saw a Federation doctor about it... she said, "No problem, Furel. You can have a new arm in less than a week... you'll have full range of motion and it'll feel just like your own."
So why didn't you do it?

Before I went into that interrogation center, I asked the Prophets to give me the strength to get the rest of you out of there. And in return... I said I'd give up my life. As it turned out, I not only rescued you and Shakaar and Lupaza... it only cost me an arm. I felt like the Prophets were generous. Somehow replacing the arm seems... ungrateful.
I think you're just afraid that with two arms, you'd actually have to do some real work for a change.
I've done more work on my farm in the last three months than you've done in three years. I've seen weeds that look better than the crops you're growing.

You know good and well that my soil's more toxic than any farm tract within a hundred kilometers. It's true. Once I get a chance to use one of the reclamators things'll change, I can promise you that.
You may not get that chance, Lupaza. Nerys was sent here by the Kai with orders to convince us to return the reclamators to the government.
And you said no...
I said I'd have to think about it.
There's not much to think about Shakaar... you know that. Tell the Kai or the First Minister or whatever she wants to be called these days that the answer's no.
We need the reclamators and that's the end of it. Now, who wants tuwaly pie?
I hope you didn't put too much rekja in it this time.
I'm not going to start taking cooking lessons from a man who can't even boil carnat legs without turning them into glue...
Now don't start that again... that happened one time...
You know... this business with the reclamators isn't going to just go away, Shakaar.
Maybe not.
Definitely not. I think you should reconsider.
I know what you're trying to do here... and I know how difficult it's been. But we need to think about what's best for Bajor.

If you think giving the reclamators back to the government is what's best for Bajor, then you've been on that space station for too long. We waited three years to get the reclamators. Two months ago, we finally got them and we were told that they were ours for at least a year. The Provisional Government actually did something right for a change. Then Minister Kalem died... and the next thing we knew, we get an order to return the reclamators immediately to... ... the Rakantha farming project.

The Rakantha project is important. If they can get it underway, Bajor could begin exporting goods again. It'll start to change how the rest of the galaxy looks at us. They'll stop seeing us as poor refugees and start seeing us as equals.
I don't give a damn about how the rest of the galaxy looks at us. We're trying to feed our own people and you're talking about exports!
Rakantha may be an important project, Kira, but they have everything: agrobiologists, chemists, and fifty reclamators. What do we have? Nothing but toxic soil and obsolete farming equipment.
There has to be a way to reach some kind of compromise here...
How?

I don't know... but maybe if you and the Kai sat down together, you could reach some kind of arrangement... some way to share the equipment more fairly. If I could arrange a meeting between you and her, would you be willing to at least talk with her about it?
I don't know if it'll accomplish anything.
It might not... but at least it's a place to start.
All right. For you... I'll meet with her.
It's good to have you home, Nerys. You should come back more often.
Maybe I will.
Good. Because we've all missed you. Especially me.
These are the codes you'll need to access my personal files in the Vedek Assembly Records. Have them transferred to this office as soon as possible.
Making yourself at home, I see.

Providing the Bajoran people with both spiritual and secular leadership is a grave responsibility. If I must abandon my offices in the Vedek Assembly to prove worthy of the task the Prophets have set before me, then so be it.
I'm sure the Bajoran people will appreciate your sacrifice.
Am I to assume, my child, that you have met with Shakaar?
We've talked.
Have you convinced him to return the soil reclamators?
He's not ready to return them... yet.
I see. And when can we expect the return of the equipment?
As soon as the topsoil in Dahkur Province has been restored and readied for planting. Another six months.
In six months, the planting season in Rakantha will be over.
I realize that... and I know how important the Rakantha project is... which is why I've arranged a meeting between the two of you.
A meeting?

Yes. To work out a compromise. If you'll just hear him out and look at the work they've been able to accomplish in Dahkur in only two months, you'll see why this is so important to them. There must be some way to resolve this situation so that both Rakantha and Dahkur can benefit.
Did you explain to Shakaar that you were there on the direct authority of the First Minister?
Yes. But it wouldn't have mattered if I were there on behalf of the Prophets themselves.
He wasn't going to just give up the equipment.
A pity. Shakaar sounds like a prideful, arrogant man. It also seems like there's no reasoning with him.

Shakaar is not an unreasonable man. He's desperate. They all are -- you should see what they're up against... the condition of the land... the harsh weather. But if you would just talk to him, I'm sure you'll be able to reach some sort of compromise.
Well. It would seem that I have little choice.
So I can tell him that you'll discuss this with him?
Yes. You can tell him that. And then you can return to Deep Space Nine.
I can still serve as an intermediary between you and Shakaar...
That won't be necessary. You've already done enough. Please, give my best regards to Commander Sisko.
That will be all, my child.
Excuse me.
My apologies. I did not intend to alarm you. I am Lieutenant Commander Syvar, Science Officer of the Garuda.
It's all right. I'm Chief Miles O'Brien. What can I do for you, sir?
I understand you are quite proficient at the human game known as "darts."
I've been known to toss a game or two.
If that means you are good, I am gratified to hear it. Ferengis have an unfortunate propensity for exaggeration and I do not wish to face an opponent of lesser skills.
I'm afraid I don't know what you're talking about.
You are not aware of our upcoming match? It was arranged by a Ferengi named Quark.
Really? Well, I guess he forgot to mention it.
I see. In that case, there will be no dishonor when you decline the match.
I... didn't say I wanted to decline.
It would be most advisable for you to do so.
Oh? And why is that?

As a Vulcan, I am better suited to this game than a human. My hand-eye coordination is superb, I am able to mentally calculate the precise trajectory necessary for each throw, and my lack of emotional attachment to the game makes me a superior dart player to any human.
When was this match supposed to take place?
Tomorrow at twenty-one hundred hours.
See you then. Sir.
Well, I'll be interested to hear what she has to say, but she's not getting those reclamators back until we're finished with them.
Shakaar... you have to be flexible. I'm not sure this is a fight you can win.
That's what the Cardassians used to say.
Come in.
Are you Shakaar?
Yes.
You're under arrest.
What? Who authorized this?
Our orders came directly from the office of the First Minister.
She lied to me.
She's good at it, Nerys. Don't feel bad.
If you'll come with us...
All right, but I want to make one thing clear...
I'm glad to see living on that space station hasn't slowed you down.
We'd better get out of here.
This can still be explained away. It was a tense situation and you acted on instinct. They'll understand that... but they won't understand you coming with me. This isn't your fight, Nerys. Go home.
I am home, Shakaar. And I've been lied to by Kai Winn for the last time. She wants a fight... I'll give her one.
... the civil police have issued a province-wide alert for you and Kira. They've requested that the surrounding towns send more men and equipment to help in the search for the "fugitives."
There's a familiar word. I haven't been called that in a while... I kinda missed it.
The authorities have seized your farm and they've brought in a scanning team to hunt for the reclamators.
Let'em scan. There's nothing there for them to find.
They've also detained some of the other members of our resistance cell for "questioning."
Who?
Mobara, Klin and Ornak were taken away before I could warn them. The others are heading for the Kola Mountain stronghold. I said we'd meet them there and go over our plan.
What is our plan?
For now... the plan is to keep moving. We'll let the civil police run themselves ragged chasing us through the mountains.
Just like old times...
That's the general idea. The Cardassians spent ten years searching for us in these mountains... the civil police will probably give up in ten days.
I'm not so sure about that... some of them used to be in the Resistance too... they might not give up so easily.

Maybe. But I don't think they really want to hunt down a group of fellow Bajorans who are just trying to defend their homes. We'll head for Kola Mountain, pick up anyone who's there and then go further up into the hill country. Let's go.
Yes!
A most auspicious shot.
You've got him, Chief. One in the bull and you win.
Julian, I think he knows that.
Don't worry "coach," I won't let you down.
I see no need for delay. Throw the dart.
I'll throw it when I'm ready.
Did I miss anything?
Shhh.
Is that my synthale?
Extra-stout, just the way you like it.
Excuse me.
Ahhh.
What is it?
It's his shoulder. It's popped out of the socket. Again. Get me a medkit.
What did I do? I just handed him a drink.
Julian... just pop it back in... I'll be fine.
I'm afraid it's not that simple this time, Chief. You have a rotator cuff tear with severe degenerative damage. We'd better get you to the Infirmary.
If he leaves the line, he has forfeited the game.
Forfeit?
Look, this man needs surgery.
Surgery?
That's right, Chief. I may have to replace the entire humoral socket. It's a simple procedure. We can postpone the conclusion of the match until tomorrow... by then his shoulder will be good as new.
I do not make the rules. I merely follow them. In any case, the Garuda is departing this evening.
Wait... wait... I'm in the zone... I just need...
I need... surgery.
I believe the House was paying... fifteen to one.
All I did was... hand him a drink...
Sisko is seated watching Kai Winn pace around the room. She's extremely agitated.
Emissary, I am so glad you came to consult with me.
Frankly, I was surprised you wanted my advice.
The advice of the Emissary is always welcome. But what I really need is your help.
What kind of help?
It's been two weeks since I was forced to send the militia into Dahkur Province.
And?
And they have yet to catch sight of Shakaar or any of his followers, let alone take them into custody.
I guess now you know how the Cardassians must've felt.

The point is, I can't let this go on much longer. It embarrasses me to say this, but Shakaar's defiance seems to be catching on in some of the other Provinces. I've had to take certain... unfortunate actions to maintain order.
You mean declaring martial law and suspending local government in the Hill Provinces.
I wasn't aware that you kept such... close watch on the Bajoran political situation.
I try to stay informed. From what I understand, Shakaar is starting to gain support all over Bajor.
Is that what Major Kira's been telling you?
I haven't spoken to the Major in quite some time.
Emissary, I don't want this issue to divide my people.
Then I'd advise withdrawing your troops from Dahkur.
I'm more than willing to do that. On one condition.
And what would that be?
I'd like you to provide a Federation security force to take their place.
You want me to bring in Shakaar for you.
Such an act would do much to solidify relations between the Federation and Bajor.
I wasn't aware our relationship needed solidifying.
Nevertheless, this is an opportunity for the Federation to once again show it's friendship to Bajor.
I'm sorry, but I'm afraid Federation law prevents me from interfering in Bajoran internal affairs.
So you're refusing my request for aid?
I suppose I am.
If Bajor cannot depend on the Federation, we'll withdraw our application for membership.

That would be an unfortunate overreaction on your part. And if I may say so, your entire response to this crisis has been an overreaction. By using militia troops against your own people, you're risking civil war over a handful of soil reclamators.

I'm afraid you can't see what's really going on here. This is not about soil reclamators. This is about the future of our society. If someone like Shakaar can defy the law and escape punishment, then we risk descending into anarchy and chaos. This is a test... a test by the Prophets.
They want to see if I'm worthy of the role they've given me as First Minister and Kai. I will not fail them. I will stop Shakaar... by any means necessary.
Move, move, move!
They're closing. Seventy-five meters.
Come on, Kira.
I've almost got it...
They're on the ridge.
Kira if you can't do it... tell me now...
I got it...
How long do we have?

I've projected the false life signs about seven hundred meters past that ravine. It'll probably take them... an hour to cover that distance... maybe another fifteen minutes to realize what's happened.
Either I'm getting older... or these mountains are getting higher.
The next time I start getting nostalgic for the old days... shoot me.
If you insist.
They're good.
Half of them are from Dahkur Province... they know the terrain almost as well as we do.
I think you're right... we need to leave Dahkur... they'll box us in if we stay much longer.
We could take Serpent's Ridge up to Ratosha Pass... and head for Lonar Province.
Serpent's Ridge is pretty rugged territory...
I'm not sure we have much of a choice.
Yes, we do. We can turn and fight.
He's right, Shakaar. It's just like in the old days... every once in a while the Cardassians would get too close... and we'd turn around and give them a bloody nose.
Sometimes it was our nose that got bloodied.
We've always been willing to take that chance. I'll follow whatever order you give... but I'm tired of running.
Kira?
I don't think we can keep up this pace.
All right. Then we'll head for Tanis Canyon. Kira's on point... column of twos after her... Lupaza take the rear.
There's no way out of Tanis Canyon...
And that's why we're going to lead those militia troops in there... because we're going to be waiting for them. Let's go.
I don't think they've picked us up on their tricorders.
They won't, either. Not with that dampening field in place.
I think I recognize that man...
Which one?
The colonel. That's Lenaris Holem.
Lenaris? From the Ornathia resistance cell?
I met him a year ago at a reception in the Capital.
He's good. No wonder we haven't lost them. We have to get him with the first volley. You take the Lieutenant on the right. I'll take Lenaris.
I'm sorry.
Don't be. I can't either.
Hold. Set a perimeter and watch the hills. No one fires until I give the order.
That's far enough.
Shakaar?
Kira Nerys.
We've met.
I've wanted to thank you for a long time. I had a brother at Gallitep when you liberated the camp.
A lot of people did. I just wish we'd gotten there sooner.
Well. I take it from your... calm demeanor that I've walked into an ambush. I should've stayed up on the ridgeline... never come down into the valley.
It's an easy mistake to make... you thought we were another two kilometers ahead and you were trying to make up time. I might've done the same thing.
I think I should tell you that I've been in worse situations.
The Pullock Five raid.
You know about that?
The first offworld raid against the Cardassians? Of course. It was a bold move.
If you know about Pullock Five, then you should also know I won't give up without a fight. So if you're here to ask me to surrender, you're wasting your time.
That's not why I'm here. I want to take my people... and walk out of here. I want to take them home.
Cease fire! Cease fire!
Wait!
Stop! No one fire!
Sir, I... I saw someone... I thought they were going to open fire...
Lieutenant.
Take this man's weapon and get him off the perimeter.
Now. I believe you were saying something about wanting to walk out of here... ?
That's right.
You know that's impossible.

Then we better find a way to make it possible or the next time someone starts shooting, we won't be able to stop it. And I'm not just talking about today... I'm talking about tomorrow and the next day and the next... I'm talking about the beginning of a civil war.
I didn't fight the Cardassians for twenty-five years so that I could start shooting other Bajorans.
Neither did I. So what do we do about it?
What is it?
Colonel Lenaris is here to see you.
Send him in.
I see you've brought me a pair of gifts. How thoughtful of you.
They're not my prisoners.
What do you mean they're not your prisoners? What's going on?
I'm here to enter the election... as a candidate for the office of First Minister.
You have an interesting sense of humor.
It's no joke. Shakaar's going to run in the election... and you're going to lose.
I've consulted with the other army commands and he has their full support.
So this is a coup.

No. It'll be a free election... if you want to run, go ahead. But if you do, this entire incident will be made public. And when the people know the real facts -- when they know that you risked a civil war over a couple of pieces of farm equipment... they'll never trust you again. You're still the Kai... the "spiritual leader of Bajor." But your days in this office are numbered... so if I were you, I'd start packing.
How's it feel?
Good so far... let's see...
Try again, Chief.
No. I can feel it... I'm out of the zone. You know... I've played sports all my life... and I've never been in the zone like that. And I probably never will again... but it felt good while it lasted.
Well, there is a bright side to all this. With that new shoulder, you might finally finish that kayaking program.
Hey. You might be right. Quark, I need a holosuite.
Doctor... welcome to the zone.
Have any other candidates entered the election?
One or two... but Shakaar's popularity is growing so fast that I don't think anyone can catch him at this point.
And what about the Kai?
She's trying to make the best of it... she even put out a statement of support for Shakaar.
Oooh. You know... I used to enjoy sleeping on the ground.
It's good to have you back, Major.
It's good to be back, sir.
I'll see you in Ops.
Sleep well, Bareil.
You're sure I can't interest you in some Yigrish cream pie.
Thank you, Doctor, but I'm quite full.
You barely touched your food.
The truth is, I've been trying to lose a little weight. Hemming women's dresses may provide me with a modest income, but it doesn't offer much in the way of exercise.
If you'd like, I could help you set up an exercise program in one of the holosuites.
I might take you up on that. But speaking of holosuites...
Happy Birthday. I know it's a few days off, but I wanted to give you your present early.
Thank you, Garak.
It's a Cardassian holosuite program. An adaptation of one of Shoggoth's enigma tales.
I see.
You sound disappointed. I thought you liked mystery novels.
I do. Human mystery novels. The problem with Cardassian enigma tales is that they all end the same way. All the suspects are always guilty.
Yes, but the challenge comes from determining exactly who is guilty of what. Is Lieutenant Dax throwing you another "surprise" party this year?
So I'm told.
You don't seem very enthused about it.
It's not that I don't appreciate all the trouble she goes to. But the thing of it is... this year's a little different.
How so?
This will be my thirtieth birthday.
And?
You know, Garak, sometimes I forget you're not human.
It's an important thing to keep in mind, Doctor.
Well, in many human cultures, the thirtieth birthday is considered a sort of milestone. It marks the end of youth and the beginning of the slow march into middle age.
And that's... considered bad?
No. It's just that... once you hit thirty, it becomes harder and harder to ignore the passage of time.
Doctor, are you trying to say that you're afraid of growing old.
Of course not. It's nothing to do with fear. I'm just having a little... difficulty accepting the aging process.
I wasn't aware that humans saw growing old as a negative experience. On Cardassia, advanced age is seen as a sign of power and dignity.

I'm well aware that aging is part of the natural cycle of life. I just don't want to be reminded of it. Look, Garak, the fact is, in two days I turn thirty, and if I want to be grumpy about it, that's my prerogative.
By all means, Doctor, be as grumpy as you want.
I appreciate the support.
Excuse me, Doctor. Do you have a moment?
What can I do for you, Quark?
Uh... my friend... Altovar here is looking to purchase a small quantity of... Bio-memetic gel. And I was wondering if you might know how he could obtain, let's say, a few hundred milliliters.
Bio-memetic gel is a restricted substance. Its sale is strictly forbidden by Federation law.
I thought so. You see. I told you.
I'm willing to pay whatever's necessary. Name your price.
Why do you need it?
That's my business.
I'm sorry, but Bio-memetic gel can be very hazardous if not handled correctly. It's not for sale. At any price.
Well, we tried. Thank you, Doctor.
Quark, you should warn your friend that even attempting to obtain Bio- memetic gel is a felony under Federation law.
I know. I told him that. But he insisted that I ask you anyway. Letheans can be incredibly stubborn. I hope you'll forgive the interruption.
You know, we just introduced a new lunch menu at the bar.
Good-bye, Quark.
Don't take it personally. He's turning thirty.
Julian. What's new?
Dax, if you're trying to find out if I know about my "surprise party" Chief O'Brien has already told me about it.
He did? That does it. That's the last surprise party I let him help me plan. Every year he insists on being involved, and every year he manages to spoil the surprise.
The chief's a man of many talents, but keeping a secret isn't one of them.

Well now that you know about it, you may as well help with the final details. We've narrowed the choices down to two different holosuite programs. Would you rather have your party at a Greek palace on Mount Olympus or at Louis Pasteur's house in Paris? Or as Quark put it, wood nymphs or can-can girls?
I'm going to have to think about that one.
Of course there's always game seven of the nineteen sixty-four World Series.
Let me guess... Commander Sisko's idea.
He says that's one of the greatest baseball games of all time.
If you care about that sort of thing. So why don't we say... Wood nymphs.
I knew it. I'll tell Quark first thing in the morning. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to have a little chat with Chief O'Brien.
It's pretty late. He's probably asleep.
Good. I'll wake him.
Lights.
What do you think you're doing?
Bashir to Security. Bashir to Ops. This is Doctor Bashir. Is anyone reading me? Computer, locate Commander Sisko. Computer, please respond... Computer?
Hello?
Is someone there?
Hello? Is anybody here?
Where is everyone?
Who's there?
Quark?
It's all right. It's me. Bashir.
What is it? What's going on? Tell me.
He's going to kill us. He's going to kill us all.
Who? Who are you so afraid of? (off Quark's frightened look) Where's Sisko? What happened to the rest of the crew?
Look, why don't you come with me? We'll go try to find them.
No. Don't you see. If we move, he'll find us. But if we stay here, we might be safe.
Safe from whom? Quark, you have to tell me.
He's here.
We've got to get these lights back on.
It's too late. He's found us. We've got to get out.
Wait.
Who's there? Show yourself.
Quark? Quark!
Tarkalean Tea?
Constable?
Garak?
What are you doing here, Doctor?
I was about to ask you the same thing.
I was looking for Constable Odo. Everyone on this station seems to have disappeared.
Not everyone. I just saw Quark. He was cowering behind his bar. He thinks someone is terrorizing the station. And I'm not sure I disagree with him.
What do you mean? Tell me what's going on.
There was some... thing in Quark's... tearing up the place. I never got a good look at it, but believe me, it wasn't friendly.
Computer.

It's no use. As far as I can tell, the station's suffered some kind of massive systems failure. Aside from life support, and simple functions like turbolifts and doors, nothing seems to be working. It's been like this for hours. I was up late programming some replicator patterns for a suit I'm designing, and everything just went dead.
I can't believe that you, Quark and I are the only people left on the station. Sisko and the others must be here somewhere.
Maybe. Or maybe they've fallen victim to some kind of rampant virus, or space anomaly, or Dominion plot.
All the more reason to try to locate them.
Wait. Do you hear that?
Hear what?
That sound. It's like voices whispering.
I don't hear anything. But then Cardassian hearing isn't quite as acute as human's. Doctor, are you feeling all right? You look... different somehow.
What is it?
Your hair. It seems to be turning gray.
So I've noticed.
I guess you had reason to worry about turning thirty after all. Either that, or your job is more stressful than I thought.
Look, Garak, we don't have time for this. We have to find out what's going on here.
I agree. Maybe we should split up. I can search the Docking Ring while you look around the Habitat Ring and the Central Core.
We'll meet back on the Promenade in an hour. Be careful.
You, too. And Doctor, try to relax.
Level H-One, Section "A."
Altovar.
Look, what are we doing standing around here?
What do you want to do? Rush out and get us all killed?
It's better than doing nothing. Let's go.
Of course. And follow you right into a trap. Is that what you want?
You're all crazy. None of this is helping us deal with the Lethean.
I say we don't do anything until we get reinforcements from Bajor.
Julian. There you are. Bajor. Bajor doesn't even Where have you been? know we're in trouble.
Looking for you. And we can't tell them unless you can get the communications system back on-line.
And we can't tell them unless you can get the communications system back on-line.

character: And we can't tell them unless
quote: you can get the communications system back on-line.
system back on-line.
Well, I'm glad you're here. It'll take hours. There's too many system's sabotaged... My work crews are all missing... I can't manufacture any new parts until we get the replicators fixed...
many system's sabotaged... My work crews are all missing... I can't manufacture any new parts until we get the replicators fixed...
work crews are all missing... I can't manufacture any new parts until we get the replicators fixed...

character: work crews are all missing... I
quote: can't manufacture any new parts until we get the replicators fixed...
until we get the replicators fixed...
The first thing we have to do is neutralize the Lethean.
The Lethean? You mean Altovar?
You know him?
We've met. He attacked me in the Infirmary.
And now he's trying to kill us all by destroying the station.
What are we waiting for? Let's get some phasers and hunt him down.
If you ask me, none of us will be safe until he's dead.
If we go out looking for the Lethean, we're the ones who'll end up dead.
Tell you what, while we're looking for the Lethean, maybe we can find your backbone.
Maybe he doesn't want us to find the Lethean. Maybe he's in league with him.
All right, that's enough. Computer, scan the occupants of this room for any anomalous readings.
Doctor, what are you doing?
You're all acting very strangely and I intend to find out why. Computer?
Don't bother, Doctor. For some reason, the computer doesn't seem to be working.
Don't go blaming me, Constable. None of this would've happened if Security had been doing its job.

Look, I said, that's enough. Where's Sisko? Where are O'Brien's work crews? I've been wandering around for hours and the only people I've seen are Quark and Garak. Where's everyone else? There's something very wrong here.
I'll say there is. Have you looked in the mirror lately?
What are you talking about?
You're face. You look... older.
If you're referring to my hair, I'm already aware--
It's more than that. You've got wrinkles.
Hold on... Does anyone else hear that?
What?
I don't hear anything.
Garak didn't either.
Julian, what are you talking about?
I know it sounds strange, but I keep hearing voices.
And he says we're acting peculiar.
So what are these so-called voices saying?
That's the problem. I can't make out the words.
I think you're the one who needs help, Doctor. Not us.
Maybe you should lie down.
I'm fine.
Except that you're hearing voices and you seem to have aged twenty- five years in the last few hours.
There has to be a logical explanation for this... maybe some kind of virus... or a subspace anomaly... A neural inversion field... anaphasic parasites...
Keep thinking, Julian. While you try to figure it out, I'm going to find the Lethean and stop him before he sabotages any more systems.
What good will that do? You don't have any idea where he is. We don't even know what we're up against. How strong is he? Can he be hurt by phaser fire?
Don't worry Chief. I'm not asking for any help from you. If he's here, I'll find him. Even if I have to do it by myself.
Dax, settle down. You're not going anywhere. Not yet, anyway. There are too many strange things going on here. My aging, the missing crewmembers, the sabotage to the station, your abnormal behavior.
You think it's all connected somehow?
I think we need to find out. Chief, is there any way to get the internal sensors on-line?
There's a computer processing junction not far from here. I might be able to repair the internal sensors from there. But I'm not going alone.
What a surprise.
Don't worry. I'm not letting you out of my sight.
We'll all go together. Let's get moving.

It's even worse than I thought. The entire sensor array is burnt out and there's extensive damage to the computer's central processor. The only system that looks salvageable is the subspace communication relay.
That would at least let us contact Bajor.
See what you can do, Chief.
Constable, would you stop doing that?
Doing what?
Looking around like that. It's getting on my nerves.
There's no harm in keeping both eyes open.
I don't remember asking for your opinion.
If the Lethean's around, I want to know it.
The last time I saw him, he was in the Central Core.
(as they continue to work) The Central Core? What level were you on?
Level Five. But I doubt he's still there. I think I lost him.
You think?
Just keep working, Chief.
For all we know, he could be right outside the door.
And if he is, then you'll have led him here.
That's fine with me, I'd just as soon finish this here and now.
Hold on Lieutenant, I think I've got the communications relay working.
Open hailing frequencies. Try to contact Bajor.
It's not working. I still can't transmit. But I'm receiving a signal. Audio only.
Let's hear it.
... four CC's of cordrazine, but there was no response.
It sounds like you, Lieutenant.
There has to be something we can do.
That's Sisko's voice.
We've tried everything we can think of, but we haven't been able to counteract the telepathic damage.
Where's this signal coming from?
I don't know. Somewhere outside the station.
Give me the bottom line.
The bottom line is that Julian's in some kind of telepathically induced coma. And unless we can get him out of it he'll be dead in less than three hours.
I'll be in my office. Keep me informed.
Don't give up, Julian. Please. You'll pull through. I know you will.
What the hell is going on here?
Delta waves. When I scan myself for brain activity, all I get are low frequency delta waves.
And what's that supposed to mean?
It means those voices were telling the truth.
I'm in a coma.
How can you stand there and say that you're in a coma? That's crazy.
Not necessarily, Major.
I suppose the next thing your going to tell us is that we're unconscious too.
Not according to these readings.
I'm glad to hear it.
Actually, I'm not picking up any life signs from you at all.
Let me see that.
You want to know what this means? It means this tricorder's broken, that's all.
I don't think so.
What are you saying, Doctor? That we don't exist?
I've had enough of this. I'm not some figment of your imagination.
But don't you see, that explains why you've all been behaving so strangely.
I'm not behaving strangely. Am I?
You all are. Dax isn't the kind of person who solves her problems by running around with a phaser. Chief, you're not usually so pessimistic.
This is a waste of time. That Lethean could be here any minute.
So if you're in a coma, and we're not real, then what are we doing here?
Maybe we're just here to give him someone to talk to.
A paranoid, a coward, a hothead, and... me? You'd think he'd pick better company.
I haven't picked anyone. I'm in a coma. I'm the only one who's really here.
Which means when I talk to you, I'm really just talking to myself.
I wish you'd stop saying that.
But there's no other possible explanation.
So you're saying that I'm you?
In a manner of speaking.
And I suppose he's you, too?
All of you are. It's like you each embody a different aspect of my personality... a different voice in my head.
I don't believe we're having this discussion.
If I had to guess, I'd say you represent doubt and disbelief.
I do not.

I knew you'd say that. Major, you're the perfect choice to represent my aggression. Odo, you embody my suspicions and fears. And Dax... to me you've always represented confidence and a sense of adventure.
Thank you, Julian.
You're forgetting something, Doctor. What about the Lethean? What's he supposed to represent?
I suppose he represents the telepathic damage that the real Lethean did to my mind.
So why is this Lethean running around sabotaging the station?

It's not the station he's sabotaging. It's my mind. The station represents my mind. Just like you represent aspects of my personality. Think about it... when Chief O'Brien fixed the communications relay, we were able to hear what was happening in the real world.
It's like he restored your hearing.
Exactly. So maybe if we can repair the station...
You'd wake up.
Yeah? And if you wake up, what happens to us?
Julian.
Jadzia!
Jadzia, Jadzia.
Ready, Doctor?
How did I get here?
Don't ask me. After all, we're in your mind. It's a shame about Lieutenant Dax.
How'd you know about that?
I'm part of you, remember? I know what you know. Maybe even a little more.
Still the man of mystery?
You wouldn't have me any other way.
I think I'm getting a little too old for this.
Apparently so. You, or should I say "we," are running out of time. Your serve, Doctor.
I can't stay here. I've got to get the main computer back on line.
Then you'd better get to Ops. If repairs are to be done, that's the place to do them.
You're right. You try to find Odo, O'Brien and Kira. Tell them to meet me in Ops.
I'd be delighted. I wonder if any of them plays tennis.
Help us... Doctor... Help... We need you...
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: I'll handle this, Doctor.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: Give this man ten milligrams of hydrocortiline. And some tripdecederine for the pain.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: What are you standing around for? You've got to get to Ops. She's suffering from cranial trauma, treat the fracture with an osteogenic stimulator and follow it up --
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: --with two CC's of inpedrezine.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: How did you know that?
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: I'm just doing my job.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: No you're not. You're doing my job.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: And doing it every bit as well as I would.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: Give him a coagulation activator to stop the bleeding.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: You must represent my skills, my professionalism.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: So what are you saying? That I'm you?
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: In a manner of speaking, yes. The best part of me.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: I'm flattered.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: Come on. You've got to come with me to Ops.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: But I'm needed here.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: If I'm going to repair this station, I'm going to need all the help I can get.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: I suppose you're right. Take care of things here. I won't be long. All right, let's--
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: You're not going anywhere, Doctor.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: You're staying right here, trapped on this station, watching while I destroy you piece by piece. And when all the best parts of you are gone, when there's nothing left but a withered shell, then, and only then, will I put you out of your misery.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: You can't escape, Doctor. You can run if you want, but you can't outrun death.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: Major.
Doctor...
Odo, what happened?
The Lethean. He came out of nowhere.
He's trying to rob me of my confidence, my strength, my intelligence... I've got to get to Ops while I still can.
Use the maintenance conduits. They're your best chance.
Chief.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: Julian... What the hell are you doing here?
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: I'm trying toget to Ops.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: You'll never make it.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: I've got to do something, don't I? I can't just let the Lethean kill me.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: Do whatever you want. It won't make any difference. The Lethean's too fast... too strong. He's going to kill us all.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: You sound awfully sure of that.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: I know you can't stop him. You look like you've got one foot in the grave already.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: I'll tell you one thing, Chief... I like the real O'Brien a lot better than you.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: Where are you going?
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: I've got to get out of these conduits. It's hard enough for me to walk, let alone crawl.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: Mind if I come along?
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: I thought you said I didn't have a chance.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: I'm hoping I'm wrong.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: So am I.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: But I doubt it.
scene: 46   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CONDUITS

quote: How did we get back here?
You tell me. It's your mind.
These monitors... they're displaying my vital signs.
What's the prognosis?
Pulse is thready... blood pressure dropping steadily... I'm dying.
I could've told you that just by looking at you.
The kidneys... the heart... brain hemorrhage... one hour... fifteen minutes...
Can I offer you gentlemen a drink?
Quark, where did all these people come from?
Just goes to show you... give the people what they want, and they'll show up in droves. Now... care to place a wager.
A wager? On what?
You name it... On how much longer you've got to live... What organ will fail first... ultimate cause of death. The house is covering all bets.
What if I want to bet that I'll survive?
It's a longshot, but if you want to throw your money away, who am I to stop you?
Dabo!
Oh-oh. Looks like all bets are off.
Including the house.
Garak. The Lethean. He's in Quark's.
He hasn't caught you yet, Doctor. Let's get you out of here.
No. I've got to go to Ops.
What's wrong?
I don't believe this. I've broken my hip. I can't walk.
Well, Doctor, it was a good game while it lasted.
I've got to keep moving.
And how do you propose to do that?
You're going to help me.
Doctor, I admire your tenacity, but I'm afraid it's over. Look at yourself. Your bones are as brittle as twigs, you can barely catch your breath, and you can't even stand, let alone walk.
But other than that, I feel wonderful. Now are you going to give me a hand or not?
It would be a privilege. Now what would you like me to do?
Help me up.
Of course.
Anyone home?
Surprise!
What's all this?
